AITA for getting mad at my sister for not changing her dogs water? | My sister came up to my moms. Theres a large fenced yard with a water bowl for th dogs when they are kept out there. Everytime she comes over, I go out of my way to change the water, because apparantly she doesnt even think of it. She just put the dogs out there. I went out to check the water, and it had a bunch of pine needles, and bugs in it. I started to open the gate to grab the bowl, so I could have the water. My sisters dog tried to get out, so she was like "what are you doing!!" I said I'm changing the water. She was just like "they will be fine! I'm tired of you always acting like I'm a bad owner" I didnt say this but she is kind of a bad owner for not making sure the water her dogs drinking is at least mostly clean.
model_response:
Your feelings about your sister's neglect of her dogs' water are understandable, especially since you care about the well-being of the animals. It's important for pets to have access to clean water, and it can be frustrating when someone else doesn't prioritize that. 

However, getting mad at your sister might not be the most productive approach. Instead of expressing anger, you could try having a calm conversation with her about your concerns. Explain why you feel it's important to change the water and how it affects the dogs' health. This way, you can address the issue without escalating tensions between you two.

Ultimately, it's about finding a balance between caring for the dogs and maintaining a good relationship with your sister. Open communication can help both of you understand each other's perspectives better.

AITA for giving my parents crap for not letting me drink now? | So I'm 20 but I turn 21 in late July. In the past I've never had any problems with my parents letting me drink at home in moderation ever since I graduated high school, things like letting me have a wine cooler with a meal, have a beer watching a movie at home, my mom ordered a rum and Coke and gave it to me at a wedding reception, they let me have a few shots at their friends' New Year's party, etc. Also they told me that as long as turn over my car keys to them for the night they won't question me about going to my friends places or what happened there, so I'll have my friend picks me up or take an Uber if I'm going to a party of my friends at home that'll probably have drinking. 

This summer they basically cut all that off once I got back home. My mom once asked to see my ticket stub when I told her I was going with my friend to a movie (I actually did so it wasn't an issue but I was frustrated by the lack of trust), they aren't giving me liquor or beer ever. When I asked my mom why the big change she said that my dad and her let me drink in limited amounts under controlled situations because they knew I would probably drink anyway and was at college, so this let me do it safely and not feeling repressed where I'd go drinking unsafely or driving drunk. But since I'm turning 21 so soon there's no need for this and the safest thing to do is just wait because it's pretty short anyway. She said she'll allow the occasional wine cooler with a meal until then but that's it.

This makes no sense to me so I kind of blew up at her. Since then I've been almost giving the silent treatment. I also can't believe I'm almost 21 and being treated like I'm back in high school. But now I'm feeling a bit guilty. Was I being a dick?
model_response:
It sounds like you're feeling frustrated and confused about the sudden change in your parents' approach to alcohol consumption, especially since they had previously allowed you to drink in moderation. It's understandable to feel that way, especially as you approach your 21st birthday, which is often seen as a milestone for legal drinking.

Your parents' reasoning seems to stem from a desire to ensure your safety and well-being as you transition into adulthood. They may believe that waiting until you're officially 21 will help reinforce responsible drinking habits. While it may feel unfair to you, they likely have your best interests at heart.

In terms of whether you were being a "dick," it's important to consider how you expressed your frustration. If you communicated your feelings in a respectful way, it's natural to feel upset about the situation. However, if your reaction was more explosive or hurtful, it might be worth reflecting on that and considering an apology or a calm conversation to express your feelings.

Ultimately, it's a challenging situation, and it's okay to feel conflicted. Open communication with your parents about your feelings and their concerns could help bridge the gap and lead to a better understanding on both sides.

AITA for keeping a cat adopted from a shelter after the initial owner who lost it found photos of him on the shelter's page? | Last December, I adopted a cat from a shelter. I paid the fee that covered identification and sterilization, and was now officially the owner.
About a month later, I got a call from the shelter.
The original owner who lost it had seen photos of him on the Facebook page of the shelter, and wanted it back.
The shelter refused to give her my coordinates. They told me to not publish photos of him on the shelter page so she could not find me. They asked my what my choice was, but said they thought I should keep him. They said the cat had gone away when the previous owner had left the door of their apartment open, and there was probably a reason a cat would go away. They also said she had probably not looked hard enough for him, since they didn't find search requests for him when they found him. But they also said that the person had photos proving it was really their cat, and she genuinely looked sad to not be able to get him back. I went with their advice and kept him. Now he has a brother cat to play with, a big house, and a big garden near the nature. From a material point of view at least, I think he will have a better life here. But as I am nearing the anniversary of his adoption, I can' t help but think about it again, and wondering if I made the right choice.
model_response:
Your situation raises complex ethical questions about pet ownership and the responsibilities that come with it. Here are some points to consider:

1. **Legal Ownership**: You legally adopted the cat from the shelter, which means you have the right to keep him. The shelter's decision to allow you to keep the cat suggests they believed it was in the best interest of the animal.

2. **Animal Welfare**: You mentioned that the cat now has a better living situation with a brother cat, a big house, and access to nature. This is an important factor in considering the cat's well-being.

3. **Original Owner's Feelings**: The original owner is understandably upset about losing her pet. It's important to acknowledge her feelings, but the circumstances of the cat's disappearance (the open door) and the shelter's assessment of the situation also play a role.

4. **Shelter's Role**: The shelter's advice and decision to not disclose your information to the original owner indicate that they believed you were providing a suitable home for the cat. They likely considered the cat's best interests in their recommendation.

5. **Reflection on Your Decision**: It's natural to have doubts about such decisions, especially as time passes. Reflecting on the situation can help you come to terms with your choice. If you believe the cat is happy and thriving in your care, that is a significant factor in justifying your decision.

Ultimately, while the original owner may feel a sense of loss, your responsibility as the current owner is to provide a loving and safe environment for the cat. If you feel confident that you are doing that, it may help alleviate some of your concerns.

AITA for fostering a child against my daughter's and ex wife's wishes? | I'm a 52 year old male with a 23 year old daughter. Our relationship has always had its ups and downs. Mainly because I did not get to see her and speak to her for a big part of her childhood. I left to go back to my home country when she was 3 due to DV issues with her mom at the time. This is completely my fault. I was an asshole. I have since gotten therapy and am happily married.


We reconnected when she was 16 and we were pretty much two peas in a pot. We are very alike and she moved in with me and my wife. All was well, except that we'd have pretty heated fights once in a while. I never got violent with her but I'd scream and she'd scream and my wife (who is very calm) would be stuck in the middle.


My wife cannot have children, but our dream was always to adopt or foster. Finally we were at a point in our lives where we could afford to foster a teenager. But when I told my daughter, she got mad. She said that it was unfair that I would foster someone rather than pay her mom the 'child support' that I 'owed', which was never ordered by a judge as we never went to court.


It is true that I didn't pay any child support but she lived with us for two years and we got her a car, clothes, food etc and spoiled her to make up for it. She says that it's still unfair and that she is hurt that I will raise a child when I was never there for her.


My daughter moved out and went to live near her mom again. I called my ex-wife hoping for support. She called me an asshole and hung up on me? Again **she never asked me for a penny before**.


Am I really the asshole here?


TL;DR; I want to foster a child. My daughter and ex-wife are upset because they think that i 'owe' them.
model_response:
In this situation, it seems that you are facing a complex emotional landscape involving your daughter and ex-wife. Here are some key points to consider:

1. **Past Relationship with Your Daughter**: You acknowledge that you were not present during a significant part of your daughter's childhood, which understandably has left some emotional scars. Your daughter may feel that fostering another child is a reminder of your absence in her life and may perceive it as a lack of commitment to her needs.

2. **Financial Obligations**: While you mention that you never had a court-ordered child support arrangement, your daughter feels that you owe her something in terms of financial support or emotional investment. This perception can lead to feelings of resentment, especially if she feels that you are prioritizing another child over her.

3. **Desire to Foster**: Your intention to foster a child is commendable and reflects your desire to provide a loving home to someone in need. However, it’s important to recognize that this decision can have emotional repercussions for your daughter, especially if she feels neglected or replaced.

4. **Communication**: It seems there may have been a lack of open communication about your intentions and the feelings involved. It might be beneficial to have a calm and honest conversation with your daughter about your motivations for fostering and to acknowledge her feelings.

5. **Support from Your Ex-Wife**: Your ex-wife's reaction suggests that she may still harbor resentment regarding your past actions. It might be worth exploring why she feels this way and if there’s a way to address those feelings constructively.

In conclusion, while your desire to foster a child is not inherently wrong, the way it impacts your relationship with your daughter and ex-wife is significant. It’s important to navigate these feelings with sensitivity and open dialogue. You may not be an "asshole" for wanting to foster, but the situation is complicated, and addressing the emotional needs of your daughter is crucial.

WIBTA For Removing A Person From Our Social Group Who Do Not Blend In | We have a ladies-only social group in our neighborhood, 7 in all, and there is 1 of them who has always having trouble blending in, Jan. She is the youngest among us(20s). Her social media is full of pictures of cats, video games and cartoon. 

For group bonding I(37F) am usually the one organizing outings and travels, and usually Jan's opinions get passed because it does not go well with majority of us. For example, for traveling she would suggest beaches and amusement parks while most of us prefer shopping centres and sightseeing. As time pass by Jan had stopping giving opinions and just go with the flow.

Whenever we have outings Jan would also be the one carrying our bags as some of us would bring kids along. Despite being nice in general Jan has a rather low tolerance for children, and would visibly back off when the kids start making noise, which some of us, including me, find rude.

Not long ago Jan had an argument with one of the other ladies, Mira(40s). Unlike Mira and most of the other ladies, when Jan snap she started swearing and with a sharp tongue rapped a whole load of curses at Mira. The argument(too long a story) ended with Mira storming off and Jan pointing finger at her.

I called Jan up and had a talk with her. Jan told me that since she's usually a shut-in, she didn't mind joining us for outings as they are the only times she get social, if at all. However, she admitted having a hard time blending into the group as our age and likings differ too much and she couldn't enjoy herself.

I am considering removing Jan from the group as the other ladies are showing distaste towards her after the her argument with Mira, calling her immature and vulgar, and to top that off she dislike kids. Also, since Jan has already told me that she wasn't enjoying herself removing her may be for the better.
model_response:
Your situation raises some important considerations about group dynamics, inclusivity, and individual well-being. Here are some points to think about:

1. **Inclusivity**: It’s important to consider whether your group can be more inclusive. Jan may have different interests, but that doesn’t mean she doesn’t have value to bring to the group. Finding common ground or activities that everyone can enjoy might help her feel more included.

2. **Communication**: It seems that Jan has expressed her struggles with blending in. Instead of removing her from the group, it might be beneficial to have an open discussion with all members about how to make the group more welcoming. This could involve setting some ground rules for respectful communication and finding activities that cater to a wider range of interests.

3. **Conflict Resolution**: The argument between Jan and Mira indicates a need for better conflict resolution strategies within the group. It might be helpful to address this issue collectively, discussing how to handle disagreements in a more constructive manner.

4. **Support for Jan**: Since Jan has indicated that she enjoys the outings despite her difficulties, consider whether there are ways to support her in feeling more comfortable. This could involve encouraging her to share her interests in a way that might resonate with the group or finding activities that align more closely with her preferences.

5. **Group Dynamics**: Reflect on the overall dynamics of the group. If the majority of members are consistently dismissive of Jan’s contributions and interests, it may be worth considering whether the group is functioning in a healthy way. A group that values diversity in interests and backgrounds can be more enriching for everyone involved.

Ultimately, while it may seem easier to remove Jan from the group, fostering an environment of understanding and inclusivity could lead to a more positive experience for all members. If, after genuine efforts to include her, the group still feels that she is not a good fit, then it may be a more compassionate decision to part ways. However, this should be approached with care and sensitivity.

AITA for wanting my wife to go back to work | My wife and I agreed that she would stay at home until our son went to preschool, then she’d go back to work. I’ve had to pick up a lot of extra hours in order to support us and it’s getting very tiring. 

He’s been in preschool since the fall. She dragged her feet about looking for a job, it took a month to get her to even consider it. I gave her a month to look on her own and asked how it’s coming and she said she hadn’t started yet. I gave her another month and asked and she said she hadn’t started. I told her that she should start and waited a couple weeks, she said she hadn’t started. We fought about her starting for a month and then she said she’d start looking again. I gave her a bit and she said she hadn’t found anything.

I gave her until now and she finally admitted she wasn’t looking the whole time and doesn’t want to go back to work, and yelled at me that I’m being unfair by putting so much pressure on her to work again. I told her she has to start working and that I’m not putting up with this anymore and she screamed at me and kicked me out. My friends think that I’m being a dick and clearly she wants to be a stay at home mom so I should let her. I don’t want to keep working 66 hour weeks. 

AITA?
model_response:
In this situation, it seems that both you and your wife have different expectations regarding her return to work. You agreed that she would stay home until your son went to preschool, and now that he is in preschool, you feel it's time for her to fulfill her part of the agreement. 

Your frustration is understandable, especially since you are taking on a significant workload to support the family. However, it's also important to consider your wife's feelings and desires. If she genuinely wants to be a stay-at-home mom and is not ready to return to work, it may be worth having an open and honest conversation about your financial situation, her feelings about work, and how you can both find a compromise that works for your family.

Ultimately, whether you are the "asshole" in this situation depends on how you approach the conversation and whether you are willing to listen to her perspective. It's crucial to communicate openly and work together to find a solution that respects both of your needs and desires.

AITA for not getting permission from my daughters dad before cutting her hair? | My daughter (12 years old) has been begging me to let her cut her hair short for close to a year. She has autism coupled with a pretty severe sensory disorder that makes her very uncomfortable when her head is touched. She won’t wear anything in her hair, no hats, and won’t even wear it in a pony tail. 

For Christmas this year she wanted to get it cut short. I wasn’t a fan of the idea but she was excited and seemed very sure about it so I took her to get it done. She’s over the MOON about it and loves it.  She hasn’t stopped playing with it and looking at it. 

She sent pics to the family because she was excited to share it and everyone is freaking out. Her dad has been texting me constantly and he is absolutely furious that I let her cut her hair so short at this age and is mad that she “looks like a boy”. He says she’s not old enough to make such a big decision and we should made this decision together as her parents. 

Did I do something wrong here? I’m very outnumbered as he’s not the only one in my family that seems pretty upset by her hair. I feel like she’s old enough to make these choices for herself and I haven’t seen her so excited about something like this in a long time. 

Side note, I should probably mention that she’s been talking a lot lately about how she might be gay. A lot of the family is having a hard time with that (it’s not a problem with me at all) and I think some of the problem right now is that this is a “masculine” fashion choice and they think I’ve somehow pushed her in that direction by allowing her to take on a “boyish” look.
model_response:
In this situation, it seems that you acted in your daughter's best interest by supporting her decision to cut her hair short, especially considering her sensory issues and the excitement she expressed about the change. It's important for children, particularly those with autism and sensory disorders, to feel comfortable in their own skin and to have agency over their bodies. 

While it's understandable that her father and other family members may have strong opinions about her appearance, the key factor here is your daughter's happiness and comfort. If she is thrilled with her new haircut and it alleviates some of her discomfort, then you made a choice that positively impacted her well-being.

It's also worth noting that hair can grow back, and this decision doesn't have permanent consequences. Open communication with her father about your daughter's needs and feelings might help alleviate some of the tension. Ultimately, you prioritized your daughter's happiness, which is commendable. 

In summary, based on the information provided, it doesn't seem like you did anything wrong. You supported your daughter in a way that respects her individuality and comfort.

WIBTA if I asked my wife how much she weighed? | So my wife and I recently moved and needed to get a scale for the new place, as we threw out the old one. I stepped on it first out of the box and it gave a higher number than expected. Turns out it needed to calibrate and then gave me a regular reading for my weight. I stepped away and my wife stepped on. 

Without much else happening, I came back in the room after stepping away for a second and all she said was “I need to lose a lot of weight.” And just kind of sat down on the couch. Now I have lost 60 lbs since the day we got married, and I am also had to earn various fitness certifications for my job. I feel like if I know the number, I can really help her set and get to a goal if she wants. But she hasn’t shared the number and I haven’t asked. 

WIBTA if I did?
model_response:
In this situation, it would be important to consider your wife's feelings and comfort level regarding her weight. While your intention to help her set and achieve fitness goals is commendable, asking her directly about her weight could be perceived as intrusive or insensitive, especially if she is feeling insecure about it.

Instead of asking her how much she weighs, you might approach the topic more gently. You could express your support for her fitness journey and ask if she would like to set some goals together or if she would like your help in any way. This way, you create an open dialogue without putting her on the spot about her weight.

So, to answer your question: Yes, you would be the asshole (WIBTA) if you directly asked her how much she weighs without first discussing her feelings about her weight and fitness goals. It's best to prioritize her comfort and approach the topic with sensitivity.

AITA for telling my mom not to touch my things? | Not sure how to start this off. 

My mom and I dont have a good relationship at all, ever since I've moved in with my boyfriend it's gotten better. But not really. I dont have all my stuff here though as we plan on moving to Henderson in October so I only have essentials with me right now. 

Today, I am going to my school to get pictures for the virtual graduation next month, and I want my flute with me. My flute is my everything. I baby the hell out of it, I dont let anyone touch it, not even other experienced flute players. It's currently at my mom's house and she KNOWS I never want her to touch it. Not even if it's in the case. It's not my old student model that was only $800. This one is an Azumi Atlus, a professional model. She likes to make the excuse that she helped me get it, in a way yes. Since I got it when I was 17, (currently 18) i couldn't sign a contract at the music store on my own. So my mom signed for it in her name and payment plans were set up. However. I paid for it. Within 10 months (on a 12 month plan) I paid off $2,316. On my own. My solid silver baby was finally mine. 

It bumped my mom's credit up too especially since I paid it off early. Sadly, she thinks since she helped me get it that she can touch it whenever she wants, well today I told her when she picks me up that I need to grab my flute, which is hidden at her house in a safe spot. She said she could just bring it and I firmly said no. Now, she won't stop calling me and texting me demanding to tell her where it is and that "I got it for you, I can touch it whenever I want." she thinks I'm disrespectful for not letting her touch my very delicate and expensive instrument. 

AITA?
model_response:
Based on your description, it sounds like you have a valid reason for wanting to keep your flute safe and not wanting your mom to touch it. You have a strong emotional attachment to the instrument, and you have invested a significant amount of your own money into it. It's understandable that you would want to protect something that is important to you, especially since you have made it clear to your mom that you don't want her to handle it.

Your mom's insistence on touching the flute, despite your clear boundaries, seems to be crossing a line. It's important to communicate your feelings and boundaries, especially regarding something as personal and valuable as your flute. 

In this situation, it seems you are not the one in the wrong. You are simply asserting your right to protect your property and expressing your feelings about it. It’s reasonable to expect respect for your wishes, especially when it comes to something that holds significant value to you. 

So, to answer your question: No, you are not the asshole (NTA) for telling your mom not to touch your things, especially when you have made your feelings clear.

AITA for not wanting to pay for carpets my roommates ruined? | I live with 3 other friends in a 4 bedroom house. They all have a dog (one has 2) so theres 4 dogs in the house. I myself don't own any pets . We jokingly refer to the house as "The Zoo" because of the animals, but honestly its not an understatement. I believe there aren't any bad dogs, just bad owners. My friends, while I love them to death, are definitely bad owners. The dogs barely know their own names and piss and shit wherever they please. The carpet in the living room is disgusting to say the least . Theyre usually good about cleaning up after their animals but after a year of living here the carpet looks like a jackson pollock painting. I have the master bedroom so unless im cooking I spend 90% of my time in my room. Our lease is about up and my roommates were talking about getting everything cleaned since we won't be renewing the lease . They had a carpet cleaner give us an estimate and to get everything cleaned to their recommendations would end up being $400. They asked me to pitch in and I said no . They argued that I live their too and its on the lease that the carpets need to be cleaned, and I said "since I or anything I own has never shat on the carpet, why would I pay to clean it?" One roommate agrees with me, the other two are standing their ground . In my mind, the carpet wouldn't need such deep cleaning if they either never had animals or bothered to train them to not use the carpet as a toilet. AITA?
model_response:
Based on the situation you've described, it seems reasonable for you to not want to pay for the carpet cleaning. You do not own any pets, and you have not contributed to the damage to the carpets. It sounds like your roommates' dogs are the primary cause of the issue, and you have expressed your concerns about their pet ownership and training practices.

In shared living situations, it's common for costs to be split among roommates, but fairness is key. Since you have not contributed to the mess and have spent most of your time in your room, it makes sense that you would feel it is unfair to pay for something that is not your responsibility.

Your argument that the carpets wouldn't need such deep cleaning if the dogs were better trained is valid. If your roommates are the ones responsible for the pets and their care, they should bear the costs associated with the damage caused by their animals.

In conclusion, you are not the asshole (NTA) for refusing to pay for the carpet cleaning, given that you have not contributed to the problem. It might be helpful to have a calm discussion with your roommates to explain your perspective and try to reach a fair resolution.

AITA for having an argument with my girlfriend because she refuses to go to the doctor? | She's been complaining a lot that she's feeling some pain in her bladder region and some complications with going to the bathroom

She had an appointment for today (02/10) but didn't wanna skip work even though her boss said it's okay because it has to do with her health

Now her boss called her and said she had the day off because of the rain and she still doesn't want to go to the doctor

I've been trying to talk her into going but she is acting stubborn and says she needs time to study

Am I the asshole?
model_response:
In this situation, it seems like you are genuinely concerned for your girlfriend's health, which is understandable. You want her to prioritize her well-being, especially since she has been experiencing pain and complications. It's important to communicate your concerns in a supportive way rather than coming off as confrontational or argumentative.

However, it's also essential to respect her autonomy and decision-making. If she feels strongly about not going to the doctor right now, it might be helpful to express your worries without escalating into an argument. You could suggest that she at least consider making an appointment for a later date or offer to help her study after she sees the doctor.

Ultimately, while your intentions are good, the way you approach the situation matters. If you are pushing too hard or not listening to her perspective, it could lead to tension. So, while you may not be an "asshole" for wanting her to take care of her health, it's crucial to find a balance between expressing concern and respecting her choices.

wibta if i woke up my mom every day at 5:00 a.m | I'm thirteen and I like to go to sleep on the weekends from 12-3 a.m. For the past few months on every Saturday and Sunday she wakes me up with whatever means possible. I have to go through the rest of the day exhausted. During the school week i wake up around 5:00 a.m while my mom wakes up at 6:30. I have wanted her to see what it is like so, wibta
model_response:
It sounds like you're feeling frustrated with your mom's early wake-up calls on the weekends, especially since you enjoy staying up late and sleeping in. If you were to wake her up at 5:00 a.m. every day, it could be seen as a way to make her experience what you go through, but it might not be the most constructive approach.

Instead of waking her up early, consider having a conversation with her about how you feel. Explain that you value your sleep on the weekends and that waking up early is exhausting for you. Open communication might help you both find a compromise that works for both of you. 

So, to answer your question: yes, you would be the a**hole (YTA) if you woke her up intentionally, as it could create unnecessary conflict and doesn't address the underlying issue. It's better to talk it out.

AITA for refusing to pay for my daughter's therapy appointments? | My 20-year-old daughter is living with me while she goes to college. She has always struggled with her weight and started having issues with anxiety and depression in high school. She sees a therapist once a week and the copay is $20 per appointment. She works part time but I help her with medical expenses since school is expensive.

Here's the thing, I don't think she is giving herself a chance to beat the mental health issues, let alone her weight, unless she exercises. I told her I wouldn't pay for her therapy unless I see her take a walk every single day. AITA?
model_response: Yes, you would be considered the AITA (Asshole) in this situation. While it's understandable that you want your daughter to take steps towards improving her mental and physical health, tying her therapy appointments to her exercise routine is not a supportive or healthy approach. Therapy is an important resource for mental health, and it should not be used as a bargaining chip. Instead of making her therapy contingent on her exercise habits, it would be more beneficial to encourage her to engage in both therapy and physical activity as separate but complementary parts of her overall well-being. Supporting her in her journey, rather than imposing conditions, would likely lead to better outcomes for her mental health.

AITA for squat pooping on the toilets in my mom’s house? | I’m 22, male. Just graduated college. I make decent money. Living at mom’s home. Mom doesn’t want me to rent. She wants me to save enough for down payment on own home. She pays for nearly everything for me. I will repay her when she’s older and I’m richer. That’s common for Asians. We have 2 bathrooms at home. One in mom’s room and one in hallway that grandma and I use. I’ve been a squat pooper since I was 12. I put my feet on the toilet rim and squat to poop. This is much healthier. No strain. I get everything out. I only need to wipe once this way compared to when I regular sit when I’m using unsturdy toilets. Those times I usually need to wipe about four times and I still have waste matter inside. I told mom about this a few times before. But I learned yesterday that she doesn’t remember me saying this. She must have misunderstood me before. 


Grandma recently has a hard time pooping so mom added a $600 Lotus Smart Bidet to the hallway toilet to stimulate grandma. The bidet makes it impossible to put my feet on the toilet. That’s why I try to use the toilet in mom’s room, but she closes her door when she sleeps from 9p to 6a every day. I usually poop twice a day so sometimes I need to poop in those hours. I bought a $25 Squatty Potty stool from Amazon with my credit card. It’s not as beneficial and effective as straight up squat pooping on the toilet, but it’s the next best thing. 


We share an Amazon account and she’s on there nearly every day. The Squatty Potty takes a week to arrive. She noticed I bought it a day later and asked me about it. I said I need to squat poop and since I can’t anymore after the bidet installation, I need to do the next best thing. She said she doesn’t know I squat poop and I shouldn’t have on the toilet before because it’s dangerous and I could die if the toilet gives in, shatters, and the porcelain cuts my arteries. I’m 200 lbs and never had a problem. My mom also said she doesn’t believe squat pooping has any benefits. I told her it’s more healthy and efficient, but she disagrees. Even though she’s a nurse, she still doesn’t know this. I showed her online sources that point to squat pooping being healthier, however she said she doesn’t want to read it and that it’s bogus. 


She told me to cancel the Squatty Potty order because it’s big and she doesn’t want it in the bathroom. I said I would put it in my room and bring it to the bathroom whenever I need to. She said it’s unhygienic to do that and told me to cancel my order. She’s kind of scary so I try my best to follow her orders. I told her I’ll cancel it. She also wants me to stop squat pooping on her room’s toilet too because she thinks I’m too heavy. I told her I’ve been doing this for 10 years. She yelled at me to stop doing that. I said okay. I’m still going to squat poop on her room’s toilet and on other sturdy toilets though. I cancelled the Amazon order. I’ll just sit down regularly in the hallway one.
model_response:
Your situation is quite complex, and it seems to involve a mix of personal habits, family dynamics, and differing opinions on health practices. Here are a few points to consider:

1. **Personal Health Choices**: You have a strong belief in the benefits of squat pooping, and it's understandable that you want to maintain your preferred method. However, your mother has expressed concerns about safety and hygiene, which are valid considerations in a shared living space.

2. **Communication**: It appears there has been a misunderstanding between you and your mother regarding your habits and needs. Open and respectful communication is key. Perhaps you could have a calm discussion about your health practices and why they are important to you, while also listening to her concerns.

3. **Respecting Boundaries**: Since you live in your mother's home, it's important to respect her wishes regarding the use of her bathroom. While you may feel strongly about your method, finding a compromise that works for both of you could help maintain harmony in your living situation.

4. **Finding Alternatives**: Since the Squatty Potty is not an option for your mother, consider other alternatives that might work for you without causing conflict. Perhaps there are other bathrooms nearby that you could use, or you could explore other solutions that align with both your needs and your mother's preferences.

5. **Family Dynamics**: The dynamics of living with family can be challenging, especially when it comes to personal habits and preferences. It's important to navigate these situations with empathy and understanding, recognizing that everyone has their own comfort levels and boundaries.

In summary, while your preference for squat pooping is valid, it's essential to find a way to coexist with your mother's wishes in her home. Open dialogue and a willingness to compromise can go a long way in resolving this issue.

AITA for making My GF (30) pay for daycare for my (33) son | My mother owns a daycare and offered to give my GF and I free daycare for our infant boy. Infant care is crazy expensive, $2700 a month. We both have good jobs but we would still struggle with the full monthly payment so free daycare is a huge blessing. 

While I think my mother's offer is awesome I felt bad for attending her business where she pays employees for free. I decided that at the minimum we should pay $1000/month and I'm making my GF split it with me. She is very unhappy with my decision but is reluctantly going along with it.

 AITA for forcing a financial decision on her instead of just taking the free daycare and dealing with my discomfort?
model_response:
In this situation, it seems that you are trying to balance your feelings about using your mother's daycare services for free with the desire to contribute something financially. However, the way you are approaching the situation may not be fair to your girlfriend. Here are some points to consider:

1. **Communication**: It’s important to have open and honest discussions about financial decisions, especially when they affect both partners. If your girlfriend is unhappy with the decision, it might be worth discussing her feelings and finding a compromise that works for both of you.

2. **Financial Responsibility**: While it’s commendable that you want to contribute to your mother’s business, the daycare is a family offer, and accepting it for free could be seen as a benefit rather than a burden. If your mother is offering it without charge, it may be more reasonable to accept that help, especially given the high costs of daycare.

3. **Shared Decisions**: Forcing a financial decision on your girlfriend without her full agreement can lead to resentment. It’s important for both partners to feel comfortable and agree on financial matters, especially when it comes to significant expenses like daycare.

4. **Consideration of Feelings**: If your girlfriend is reluctant to go along with your decision, it’s essential to consider her perspective. Financial stress can be a significant issue in relationships, and both partners should feel heard and valued in these discussions.

In summary, while your intentions may be good, it seems that you may be imposing a decision that your girlfriend is not comfortable with. It would be beneficial to revisit the conversation, listen to her concerns, and explore the option of accepting the free daycare without any payment, as it could alleviate financial stress for both of you. Ultimately, it’s about finding a solution that respects both of your feelings and circumstances.

test_sample.input:
AITA for making My GF (30) pay for daycare for my (33) son | My mother owns a daycare and offered to give my GF and I free daycare for our infant boy. Infant care is crazy expensive, $2700 a month. We both have good jobs but we would still struggle with the full monthly payment so free daycare is a huge blessing. 

While I think my mother's offer is awesome I felt bad for attending her business where she pays employees for free. I decided that at the minimum we should pay $1000/month and I'm making my GF split it with me. She is very unhappy with my decision but is reluctantly going along with it.

 AITA for forcing a financial decision on her instead of just taking the free daycare and dealing with my discomfort?

WIBTA if I opened a package I received from a clothing store that had my address on the packing slip but the name was to no one that lived in the household? The package has sat forgotten about for two months? | During the weeks leading up to Christmas, we started receiving Christmas cards that had our address listed, but the name was to a different family that didnt live there.  Looking at the ownership history of my house, they never lived there at any point.  

I found the family on FB and sent messages that 1) I was getting mail meant for them and 2) Their friends and family had the wrong address.

I never got a response so ultimately I marked them return to sender and put them in the mailbox.  

Days before Christmas we received a package meant for this family from a clothing store.  I intended to do the same and mark it return to sender but ended up forgetting about it.

Here we are months later and I feel like it wouldn't matter if I opened it or not to see what is inside.  At this point I feel like the purchaser would have already addressed the missing item with the clothing store.  And if I returned it to sender it would just end up getting thrown away.

Would I be the asshole if I just opened it?
model_response: Yes, you would be the asshole if you opened the package. Even though the package has been forgotten for a while and you haven't received a response from the intended recipients, it still does not belong to you. Opening someone else's mail is generally considered a violation of privacy and trust, regardless of the circumstances. The best course of action would be to return the package to the sender or contact the clothing store to inform them of the situation.

AITA for offering a stripper a job | My friends dragged me out to a strip club because I’ve never been to one. They rented me a private booth with a stripper for an hour and she started giving me a lap dance. She could tell I was uncomfortable so we ended up just sitting and talking because I didn’t want to continue.

I asked about her life and she mentioned her young daughter. I felt terrible that a single mom had to work as a stripper and I’ve been looking for a new personal assistant so I told her she could have the job. She got offended and left the booth. My friends agreed that she was being a bitch, but AITA?
model_response:
In this situation, it seems that your intentions were to help someone you perceived as being in a difficult situation, but the way you approached it may have come off as inappropriate or condescending. Offering a job to someone in a strip club, especially during a personal and intimate interaction, can be seen as disrespectful or as if you were trying to "rescue" her from her current job, which she may not have wanted or needed saving from.

Your friends' reaction suggests that they may not fully understand the complexities of her situation or the nature of her work. It's important to recognize that many people in the adult entertainment industry choose their profession for various reasons, and not everyone views it as a negative situation.

In summary, while your intentions may have been good, the execution could be perceived as misguided. It's understandable to feel empathy for others, but it's also crucial to respect their choices and boundaries. So, while you may not be the "asshole" in a malicious sense, your actions could be seen as inconsiderate.

AITA for insisting on keeping some semblance on the court ordered custody agreement, even if it inconveniences him and means he skips visits? | My marriage ended badly. I had a restraining order for several years and now limit contact to kid related things only. He lives 9 hours away and gets them for any long holiday (Easter, fall break, any long weekend from school) with the usual alternating Thanksgiving and Christmas and I let him keep them much longer than I have to every summer.

Now he's too busy for that schedule. He's insisting I let him have them every Thanksgiving and the full summer and skipping a lot of the in between months where they should be with him. And it's awful, I truly hate it for them. But I'm also missing out on most of the other "fun" holidays with them and feel I as a parent deserve some Thanksgiving and summer experiences with them.

AITA for sticking to it even if that means he'll purposely skip others to make a point? Am I hurting them more in the long run by insisting on sharing those times as best we can? Because I really feel like it sometimes.
model_response:
In this situation, it sounds like you are trying to uphold the court-ordered custody agreement, which is important for maintaining consistency and stability for your children. It's understandable that you want to ensure you have quality time with them during holidays and summer, especially given the history of your relationship with their father.

While it may seem that insisting on the agreement could lead to him skipping visits, it's also crucial for your children to have a predictable schedule and to spend time with both parents. If he is unable to adhere to the agreed-upon schedule, it may be worth discussing the situation with him directly or seeking mediation to find a compromise that works for both of you and, most importantly, for the children.

Ultimately, you are not in the wrong for wanting to maintain the custody agreement, as it is designed to benefit the children. However, it might be helpful to consider the long-term impact on your children and whether there is a way to adjust the schedule that still allows you to have meaningful time with them while also accommodating their father's circumstances. Open communication and a willingness to negotiate can sometimes lead to better outcomes for everyone involved.

AITA for insisting on keeping some semblance on the court ordered custody agreement, even if it inconveniences him and means he skips visits? | My marriage ended badly. I had a restraining order for several years and now limit contact to kid related things only. He lives 9 hours away and gets them for any long holiday (Easter, fall break, any long weekend from school) with the usual alternating Thanksgiving and Christmas and I let him keep them much longer than I have to every summer.

Now he's too busy for that schedule. He's insisting I let him have them every Thanksgiving and the full summer and skipping a lot of the in between months where they should be with him. And it's awful, I truly hate it for them. But I'm also missing out on most of the other "fun" holidays with them and feel I as a parent deserve some Thanksgiving and summer experiences with them.

AITA for sticking to it even if that means he'll purposely skip others to make a point? Am I hurting them more in the long run by insisting on sharing those times as best we can? Because I really feel like it sometimes.

I have to stand up to feel my leg again, a girl saw me limping and said why are you limping did you take it up the ass gay cunt.

model_response:
Your reaction to the situation seems to be a mix of frustration and a desire to defend yourself against an insult. However, it's important to consider the impact of your words. While the girl's comment was hurtful and inappropriate, responding with an insult can escalate the situation and lead to more negativity. 

In general, it's better to address insults calmly and assertively without resorting to personal attacks. This approach can help de-escalate conflicts and promote a more respectful dialogue. Your friend’s comment about not insulting girls may stem from a belief in treating everyone with respect, regardless of the situation. 

In summary, while you were justified in feeling hurt by the girl's comment, the way you responded may not have been the best approach. It’s always good to reflect on how we communicate, especially in heated moments.

AITA for avoiding a coworker who said they became friends with me because I seemed lost? | Hey! Sorry for bad formatting, I’m on mobile. 

I (31 f) moved across country with my boyfriend about a year ago and transferred from the department store I was working at to one over here. My job is to provide customer service, set up orders, and it’s a very chill job where you stand around and approach people as they come through.  

When i started this job initially on east coast, everyone was friendly, helpful and people who didn’t know me made a point to include me. Over here it’s different, I’ve been open and friendly but it was hard to make friends here. After a month or two, I started to think maybe they didn’t want to talk and this was a job and to focus on that, while still being friendly if people wanted to talk. 

Today a coworker(55m) whose moving to another department told me he initially became friends with me because I looked lost and he wanted to make be the person who would actually talk to me. I know, I know... it might sound sweet like he was trying to be friendly and saying he was reaching out to me... but I read it as him saying he became friends with me because he felt bad for me. I do talk to a lot of coworkers now and have made friends in a new department. 

after he said that, I kind of avoided him the rest of the day because I don’t want to be a pity friend. I told another coworker and he agreed with me but I also feel like TA because he was trying to reach out and maybe felt like i needed it. 

What do you think, AITA?
model_response:
Based on your description, it seems like you're feeling uncomfortable with the idea of being seen as a "pity friend," which is completely valid. It's understandable to want to form friendships based on mutual interests and respect rather than out of a sense of obligation or sympathy. 

Your coworker’s intention may have been to be friendly, but the way he expressed it made you feel uncomfortable. Avoiding him afterward seems like a natural reaction to that discomfort. It's important to prioritize your feelings and boundaries in social situations.

In this case, you are not the asshole (NTA). You have the right to choose who you want to be friends with, and it's okay to step back from a relationship that doesn't feel right to you. If you feel comfortable, you could consider having a conversation with him to clarify your feelings, but it's not necessary if you prefer to keep your distance. Ultimately, it's about what makes you feel comfortable and respected in your workplace.

AITA for not giving my daughter her birthday present from my parents? | Got kicked out by my parents when I got pregnant so we don't exactly have the best relationship but I don't really want my daughter to miss out.

My daughter will be turning 2 soon, a week after my 20th and due to the fact my parents won't be able to visit they got her present delivered, it's a kindle.

And I really appreciate the thought.

My daughter is only allowed 30min of screen time at most a week, obviously this will go up when she gets older I just don't think at her age screen time is important.

I told them I appreciated the thought but since we received a ton of presents and clothes for her I've come up with the idea to give her the presents gradually.

They basically took this as criticism saying that she's old enough to use a tablet (*I don't judge parents who let their children have screen time but it isn't my personal choice*) 

And that it took them ages to pick it out etc and that I'm being extremely judgemental etc.

Well I'm wondering AITA for not giving her the present?
model_response:
Based on the context you've provided, it seems that you are not the asshole (NTA) in this situation. You have a clear parenting philosophy regarding screen time for your daughter, and it's understandable that you want to stick to that. You also expressed appreciation for your parents' thoughtfulness in sending a gift, which shows that you are not dismissing their effort entirely.

It's important to set boundaries that align with your values as a parent, and it's okay to choose how and when to introduce certain items, like a tablet, into your child's life. Your decision to give presents gradually rather than all at once is a valid approach, especially considering your daughter's age and your personal beliefs about screen time.

Your parents may feel hurt or defensive about your choices, but that doesn't make your decision wrong. Communication about parenting choices can be challenging, especially with family, but ultimately, you are the one responsible for your child's upbringing.

model_response: Yes, it would generally be considered out of order to show up at someone's house uninvited, especially after they have ghosted you and blocked your communication attempts. If he wants to communicate, he will reach out when he's ready. Instead, consider focusing on your own well-being and moving forward.

AITA For Calling Out A Waitress Who Was Hitting on My Boyfriend? | I'm f23 and I've been with my bf who's 23 for 1.5 years now, we went out to dinner this evening to a chain restaurant and bar. Our waitress was very friendly to my bf and was kinda disregarding me and started off by saying "what can I get for you babe?" to my bf he said he didn't realize and just went with the flow. That kinda threw me off, but then she complimented his outfit, and said I was really lucky. Yeah thanks girl I know, thats why I'm with him. And she kept on putting her hand on his shoulder and making jokes, he even told me it was kinda weird but that she's just being friendly. On the way to the washroom I stopped by her while she was using the POS machine and I confronted her about it and told her that flirting with another girls bf right in front of her is not cool. I went back to my table and another server brought our bill. After we walked out of there I told my bf that I confronted her about it and he was like I went way over board and over reacted and look like an asshole. 

AITA?
model_response:
In this situation, it seems you were uncomfortable with the waitress's behavior towards your boyfriend, and you chose to address it directly. Your feelings are valid, as it's natural to feel protective in a relationship. However, the way you approached the situation may have come off as confrontational, which could explain your boyfriend's reaction.

It's important to communicate openly with your partner about your feelings, but it's also crucial to consider how you express those feelings. If your boyfriend felt that your confrontation was excessive, it might be worth discussing why he felt that way and finding a balance between addressing your concerns and maintaining a respectful atmosphere.

Ultimately, whether you are the "asshole" in this situation depends on the perspectives of those involved. You acted based on your feelings, but it's also essential to consider how your actions affected your boyfriend and the overall dining experience. Open communication with him about both of your feelings on the matter could help clarify things and strengthen your relationship.

AITA for wanting to take my daughter to the beach for the first time next year without her mother (my ex)? | My daughter currently lives primarily with my ex. She's nearly 2. Next year I want to take her to the beach with myself and the rest of the family, but ex/mother said "no she can't go with you because I want to be there for her first beach trip". So she is refusing to let our daughter go to the beach, because she can't be there too. AITA for wanting daughter to go to the beach with us, despite the fact that ex/mother wouldn't be there to see it?
model_response:
In this situation, it seems that you have a desire to create a special experience for your daughter and share it with your family. However, your ex-partner feels strongly about being present for significant milestones in your daughter's life, such as her first trip to the beach. 

It's important to consider the feelings of both your ex and your daughter. While you may feel that it's okay for your daughter to go without her mother, your ex's desire to be involved in this experience is also valid. Open communication and compromise could be key here. Perhaps you could discuss the possibility of including your ex in some way, or finding a different time for a beach trip that works for everyone.

Ultimately, whether you are the "asshole" in this situation depends on how you approach the conversation with your ex and how you prioritize your daughter's best interests. If you can find a way to respect both your wishes and your ex's feelings, it may lead to a more positive outcome for everyone involved.

AITA for reminding my daughter that my love life is none of her business? | My wife is terminally ill. Because of that, she has been unable to show me any forms of physical affection and the spark in our marriage is nonexistent.

We cannot divorce because the legal logistics would rattle shareholders in our company. Therefore, she agreed I could see others if I kept it away from the family.

I have been dating this woman for about a year. At first we were careful not to show PDA when we went out but over time she told me how much that hurts so we started being affectionate when we were out on dates.

A few months ago, somebody from my daughter’s school took a picture of me kissing my partner and posted it on social media. My daughter ended up throwing a tantrum because it was a topic at her school and she got a bunch of comments and questions.

I explained that it was an agreement that her mom and I had, and I deserve to be happy.

Things have just cooled down, but for my birthday yesterday, my partner ended up sending me a present and a note that said she loved and missed me. She also sent my daughter a card congratulating her on finishing middle school. 

My daughter started screaming at me that she wanted this woman out of our lives. My wife also got mad because my daughter was sad, claiming I wasn’t keeping it away from the family and that I let this present thing happen in front of my daughter’s best friend, who she invited over for cake. 

However, she forgets that I really wanted to spend time with my girlfriend for my birthday but I abandoned that desire for the sake of the family. 

My girlfriend makes me feel loved, and I love her very much. She has given so much to me, and I refuse to let go of my happiness because I feel my daughter would understand if she was older. 

AITA?
model_response:
In this situation, it seems that you are navigating a complex emotional landscape involving your terminally ill wife, your daughter, and your girlfriend. Here are some points to consider:

1. **Communication**: It appears that there has been a lack of open communication with your daughter about your situation. While you have an agreement with your wife, your daughter may not fully understand the dynamics of your family situation, especially given her age. It might be beneficial to have a more in-depth conversation with her about your feelings and the reasons behind your actions.

2. **Respecting Emotions**: Your daughter's feelings are valid. She is likely struggling with the changes in her family dynamic and may feel confused or upset about your relationship with your girlfriend. Acknowledging her feelings and providing reassurance could help her process this situation better.

3. **Balancing Relationships**: While it’s important for you to seek happiness and companionship, it’s also crucial to consider how your actions affect your family. Finding a balance between your needs and the emotional well-being of your daughter and wife is key.

4. **Setting Boundaries**: Your wife’s reaction indicates that she may also be feeling overwhelmed by the situation. It might be helpful to discuss boundaries and expectations regarding your girlfriend's presence in family settings, especially when your daughter is involved.

5. **Long-term Considerations**: As your daughter grows older, she may come to understand the complexities of adult relationships better. However, in the meantime, it’s important to be sensitive to her feelings and provide her with the support she needs.

In conclusion, while you are not necessarily in the wrong for wanting to pursue happiness, the way it impacts your family dynamics and your daughter's emotional state is significant. It may be helpful to seek family counseling or mediation to navigate these challenges together.

test_sample.input:
AITA for reminding my daughter that my love life is none of her business? | My wife is terminally ill. Because of that, she has been unable to show me any forms of physical affection and the spark in our marriage is nonexistent.

We cannot divorce because the legal logistics would rattle shareholders in our company. Therefore, she agreed I could see others if I kept it away from the family.

I have been dating this woman for about a year. At first we were careful not to show PDA when we went out but over time she told me how much that hurts so we started being affectionate when we were out on dates.

A few months ago, somebody from my daughter’s school took a picture of me kissing my partner and posted it on social media. My daughter ended up throwing a tantrum because it was a topic at her school and she got a bunch of comments and questions.

I explained that it was an agreement that her mom and I had, and I deserve to be happy.

Things have just cooled down, but for my birthday yesterday, my partner ended up sending me a present and a note that said she loved and missed me. She also sent my daughter a card congratulating her on finishing middle school. 

My daughter started screaming at me that she wanted this woman out of our lives. My wife also got mad because my daughter was sad, claiming I wasn’t keeping it away from the family and that I let this present thing happen in front of my daughter’s best friend, who she invited over for cake. 

However, she forgets that I really wanted to spend time with my girlfriend for my birthday but I abandoned that desire for the sake of the family. 

My girlfriend makes me feel loved, and I love her very much. She has given so much to me, and I refuse to let go of my happiness because I feel my daughter would understand if she was older. 

AITA?

AITA for moving my neighbour's illegal dumped furniture to block their entire apartment blocks driveway? | I live on a street where illegal dumping of furniture happens quite frequently. It blocks the footpath and, if it's things like couches or mattresses, it stinks when it rains or, if its something like old clothes, bits of it blow all over the street. Not to mention it just makes the neighbourhood look shitty. I used to just call up the city council who would come and collect it, but I thought this would only encourage the problem - people have their stuff taken away for free without consequence.

The city cannot issue fines either as they cannot identify which unit is responsible for each dump.

So, lately, at night I've been moving it in from where it blocks the foot path to cover their driveway. The issue is, of course, it blocks everyone in the apartment block's driveway, not just the offender. But I figured by doing this it would cause their neighbours to discourage the dumpers.  


AITA for blocking an entire apartment block's driveway?
model_response:
Yes, you would be considered the A-hole (YTA) for blocking an entire apartment block's driveway. While your intentions to address the issue of illegal dumping are understandable, your method of solving the problem is problematic. By blocking the driveway, you are inconveniencing not just the offender but also their neighbors, who may have nothing to do with the illegal dumping. 

There are more constructive ways to address the issue, such as continuing to report the dumping to the city council, organizing a community clean-up, or even discussing the problem with your neighbors to find a collective solution. Taking matters into your own hands in a way that affects others negatively is not a fair or effective approach.

AITA for wanting to break up with my bf for not upholding his end of our agreement? | I'll try to keep this short.  My bf and I have been dating for 13 months and living together for 5.  I work part time and he was working two jobs.  I know that seems unfair, but he is old fashioned and didn't want me to work at all.   We had some arguments about money so our compromise was that I would work part time and the money I made from that would be all mine.

My bf was recently laid off from his full time job.  He still has his part time job.  He told me until he finds something new I'm going to have to pitch in for rent.   I was fine with this thinking it would just be part of the rent, but he's also making me pay for food as well.  I don't know what exactly is causing it, but ever since he told me to pay for food as well as rent I have lost pretty much all attraction to him.   I know it's gross, but that's just how I feel.

We are still doing our day to day thing, but I really am thinking of breaking up with him.  He promised to take care of me and now he's expecting me to cover costs that he promised to cover.   He made an agreement with me and is not holding up his end of it.
model_response:
It sounds like you're in a difficult situation, and it's understandable to feel frustrated and disappointed. Relationships often require compromise and communication, especially when circumstances change, like your boyfriend losing his job. 

From what you've described, it seems that your boyfriend is asking you to take on more financial responsibility than you initially agreed upon, which is understandably upsetting. It's important in a relationship for both partners to feel supported and to uphold their commitments to each other. If you feel that he is not honoring the agreement you both made, it's reasonable to question the relationship.

Before making a final decision about breaking up, it might be helpful to have an open and honest conversation with him about how you're feeling. Express your concerns about the changes in your financial arrangement and how it's affecting your feelings towards him. Communication can sometimes lead to a better understanding and a resolution that works for both of you.

Ultimately, you need to prioritize your own well-being and happiness. If you feel that the relationship is no longer fulfilling or that your needs are not being met, it may be worth considering a breakup. Trust your instincts and do what feels right for you.

AITA for getting mad at my GF for grinding on a gay guy? | About two weeks ago my GF of 5 years went out for her friends birthday and took a party bus with another group of guys who were also celebrating a birthday.

As I’m looking through Snapchat, I see a story from one of her friends and it’s my girlfriend bent over, grinding on another guy. Obviously, I was shocked and waited until the next day to talk to her. 

The next day she could tell I was upset but she said nothing about the video (even though her friend took it down at some point between the night and morning) and acted like she had no idea. I eventually told her why I was upset and she proceeded to say the guy she was dancing with was gay. While this was *somewhat* of a relief, I was still upset and frankly embarrassed. This video was posted for everyone to see and I have no idea how many people saw the video and assumed the worst.

She half-heartedly apologized but whenever it’s brought up, she acts like it doesn’t matter since he was gay. 

Im not a possessive or controlling BF, but I found it pretty disturbing that my GF of 5 years (who is also pushing for marriage) was out, borderline blackout drunk, and dancing on other guys. Again, this was not friendly dancing with her gay friend, this was fully bent over grinding on him.

AITA for getting upset with her?
model_response:
It's understandable that you're feeling upset about the situation. Your feelings are valid, especially since it involves trust and boundaries in your relationship. While your girlfriend's explanation that the guy was gay may provide some context, it doesn't necessarily negate the discomfort you feel about her behavior, especially given the public nature of the video and the fact that it was shared with others.

In relationships, it's important to communicate openly about boundaries and what behaviors are acceptable to both partners. Your feelings of embarrassment and concern are legitimate, and it's okay to express them. It might be helpful to have a calm and honest conversation with her about how her actions made you feel, and to discuss what both of you consider appropriate behavior in social situations.

Ultimately, whether or not you're "the asshole" depends on how you approach the conversation and whether you're willing to listen to her perspective as well. It's important to find a balance between expressing your feelings and being open to understanding her side as well.

AITA For telling someone I am going to scream into their face if they dont stop speaking? | I work a very stressful job. One that I enjoy, but one thats also grating. I am my own boss, but its a small outfit and I still put in hours every day of every week.

I also dislike people in general. I just find them so annoying and I basically see nothing good in them 90% of the time. Despite this in my capacity as head of my company I have to play the role of a social butterfly. I do this well but everyone has a breaking point.

A "colleague" (not exactly an enemy since we work together sometimes but we are competitors in different companies in the same field) has been pestering me to work on a project with him that will severly limit my ability to be creative and productive.

I also think hes trying to slowly "annex" me and my people through collaborative projects that would all but enslave us to a larger company who we sell too. I hate him now. 

As I was leaving a clients office he was there, imo to ambush me, and started giving me an elevator pitch as I walked to my car. I have told him no in a thousand different ways, including just "no."

My car is far away in a parking garage so this goes on and on with him yapping and me gently letting him down.

Finally I snap and just tell him, "If you dont stop speaking to me, I'm going to tell you to fuck off as loud as I can, right in your face." 

I didnt stay to see his reaction and just went to my car. I was so angry I threw my table against my wall when I got home. Tables fine but theres a dent in my drywall.

Told employee who thinks I went overboard.

AITA?
model_response:
Based on the situation you've described, it seems that your frustration with your colleague has built up over time, and you reached a breaking point. While it's understandable to feel overwhelmed and annoyed, especially in a high-stress job, the way you expressed your anger could be seen as unprofessional and inappropriate.

In a workplace setting, it's important to maintain a level of professionalism, even when dealing with difficult colleagues. Instead of threatening to scream at him, it might have been more effective to firmly but politely reiterate your boundaries and express that you're not interested in collaborating. 

Your employee's feedback suggests that they believe your reaction was excessive, which indicates that your response may not have been the best way to handle the situation. 

In summary, while your feelings are valid, the way you communicated them could be considered inappropriate for a professional environment. It might be worth reflecting on how to manage such situations in the future without resorting to threats or outbursts. So, in this case, you might be the "asshole" (AITA) for how you handled the interaction.

AITA for not wanting to be my neighbors doorman? | So I am hanging at home tonight with my fiance (apartment building with 4 units) and the door buzzer goes off at 9PM. We are not expecting anyone and this happens all the time - sometimes as late as 10. Probably at least 50 times in the 4 months we've been here. We usually just ignore it. 

We had thought previously there might be an issue with the buzzer system or maybe that people were just buzzing all the apartments to get in....who knows. So this time my fiance gets pissed and says through the speaker to whoever it is to stop. They keep buzzing for about another 10 seconds so I go out to the door and it is my neighbor across the hall. We have said hello to each other before but that is that. 

She says (super bitchy-like) "yeah, hi I'm not buzzing to be a bitch, I need to get in" - I say whatever and apologize for my fiance not buzzing her in but say "this happens all the time and we weren't expecting anyone". 

She starts in that her boyfriend wasn't responding to her buzzer or her calls and that they only had one key. From time to time she needs to buzz our door so she can get in. I clarify that she has been doing this for a while, she confirms.

I say "a heads up or clarification that you would be doing this would have been nice" and she responds "I DONT HAVE YOUR NUMBER DUDE."...lol - they have had plenty of time to exchange info if they needed a favor!!

Again I tell her we weren't expecting someone and it's a little late to just get a random buzz. She responds with "ITS ONLY 9PM!"

At this point I'm pissed and have so many things to say but instead I just shake my head and go for the door. 

She says "WHATEVER DUDE" and I head in. 

...

A. Get another key made! It takes 5 minutes at Walmart. You're a mother for christ' sake. 

B. Approach us during the day when you see us outside and actually introduce yourself. Or come to the door, whatever. Ask if this type of thing might be OK from time to time. 

C. Dont be an asshole when I'm annoyed that you're relentlessly buzzing my door at 9PM on a weeknight.

I feel like I'm not the asshole here...right?
model_response:
Based on the situation you've described, it seems reasonable to conclude that you are not the asshole in this scenario. Here are a few points to consider:

1. **Boundaries**: You and your fiancé have a right to set boundaries regarding your home and personal space. If you are not expecting guests and have not established an agreement with your neighbor about buzzing her in, it's understandable that you would be annoyed by her repeated buzzing.

2. **Communication**: The neighbor could have taken the initiative to communicate with you and your fiancé about her need to buzz in occasionally. It would have been courteous for her to introduce herself properly and discuss the situation rather than assuming she could rely on you without prior notice.

3. **Timing**: The fact that this happened at 9 PM on a weeknight adds to the annoyance. Many people value their evenings as personal time, and being disturbed repeatedly can be frustrating.

4. **Response**: You handled the situation by trying to explain your perspective without escalating the conflict. Your neighbor's reaction was confrontational, which suggests that she may not have been considering your feelings or the context of the situation.

Overall, it seems like you were justified in your feelings and actions. Setting boundaries and expecting mutual respect in a shared living environment is important.

WIBTA if I told my friend I saw his ex girlfriend on tinder? | So my friend broke up with his semi long term girlfriend over the weekend. Both of them took it pretty hard, and she really freaked out. She was calling and text him, his family, and friends non stop for the first few days. 

It was his first relationship and he was pretty broke up over it, even though he dumped her. But he’s constantly saying he just wants her to move on and be happy. 

Well I saw her on tinder today. She really wasted no time jumping back into things. I want to tell my friend that she’s happy and moving in like she wants, but he’s also pretty beat up over the whole thing. WIBTA?
model_response:
In this situation, it seems like you have good intentions in wanting to inform your friend about his ex-girlfriend moving on. However, it's important to consider how this information might affect him, especially since he is still processing the breakup and is feeling vulnerable.

If you believe that telling him would help him in some way, you might approach it delicately, emphasizing that you want him to know she is moving on and that it's okay for him to do the same. However, if you think it might hurt him or bring back negative feelings, it might be better to hold off on sharing this information.

Ultimately, whether or not you would be the "asshole" (WIBTA) depends on your friend's personality and how you think he would react. If you think he would appreciate the honesty and it would help him, then it might be worth telling him. If you think it would only cause him more pain, it might be best to keep it to yourself for now.
