AITA for telling my husband his tattoo ideas are stupid and I'd be embarrassed to be seen with him if he gets them? | Hey guys,


My husband's always been into tattoos. I'm not a fan of them at all, however he did have them since before we got together, and I learned to ignore them. He's casually talked about getting more every so often, though in the 9 years we've been together he hasn't, and any time it comes up and he asks what I think, I do let him know I don't like the idea of him getting more tattoos, but ultimately it's his choice. I won't be mad about it, but I'm not going to share his excitement.


Anyways, so he finally decided he's ready to get more... and he wants to get writing on his arm saying "CREAM Git dat money $$$" and his hands to say "THERE IS" and "NO GOD" with devil horns on one side and an upside cross on the other. I'm not gunna lie, I absolutely thought he was joking. At first I was like haha, very funny, so what do you want to get? And... yeah. That's it, apparently. I was so shocked I couldn't even say anything for a minute. For context, we do live in a more upper class area, but a smaller town, and while yes people have tattoos here, absolutely not something like that. He would stand out like a sore thumb, and honestly so would I, and while it may be shallow I'd rather my boss and coworkers not know me as the lady married to the dude with GIT DAT MONEY$$$ tattooed on him.


I was, and I admit, maybe a little too brutally honest. I told him, "I know you want tattoos and all but... that's a horrible idea. Honestly it's really stupid and immature and I would be embarrassed to be seen around you if you really got that." He told me I was crazy, that those are awesome ideas and he loves those sayings, and that he doesn't see what my problem is. I told him my problem is that that's something a wannabe gangster teenage would tattoo on his arm to try and act cool.


He got pretty upset and said he put alot of thought into this and it wasn't cool of me to tear him down like that, and even if I don't like it I should be supportive. I don't see any way I could support it whatsoever. It's a horrible idea and I am completely against it. AITA for being so harsh about it though? I just really wanted to make sure he got the point.
model_response:
In this situation, it seems that you were honest about your feelings regarding your husband's tattoo ideas, but the way you expressed your opinion may have come off as harsh and dismissive. While it's understandable to have concerns about the tattoos and how they might affect both of you socially or professionally, the way you communicated your thoughts could be seen as undermining his autonomy and creativity.

It's important to remember that tattoos are a personal choice, and your husband has the right to express himself in a way that feels authentic to him, even if you don't agree with it. Instead of labeling his ideas as "stupid" or "immature," it might have been more constructive to express your concerns in a way that acknowledges his feelings and choices. For example, you could have said something like, "I understand that these tattoos are meaningful to you, but I'm worried about how they might be perceived in our community."

Ultimately, while you have valid concerns, the way you communicated them may have hurt your husband's feelings and made him feel unsupported. It might be helpful to have a follow-up conversation where you can both express your perspectives more openly and respectfully. So, while you are not necessarily the "asshole" for having your opinion, the way you conveyed it could be seen as insensitive.

AITA for not telling my sister about my winnings? | To preface; I won just under £3 million on the lottery over two months ago. The NL have been extremely helpful and supportive and gave me lots of financial advice and I've taken it all on board. While I chose to remain anonymous, I did tell my little sister about the winnings, pretty much the second the money hit my account. I still haven't told my mum, I know for sure she would tell everyone she has ever met that I won the lottery and that is absolutely not what I want.  


Me, my sister and mum all live in a small house owned by my older sister, we all used to live here together for many years until my sister bought a house with her partner. We pay her rent, a very small amount and we pay our own utilities. My sister has always hoped she can eventually sell this house to us but neither me nor my little sister have ever had the money. My little sister has a secure job but not very high paying and I am a casual worker so getting a mortgage would be hard for me. After winning, I decided to look for houses that we could move into, ideally one with a large kitchen and garden for my mum and finally found an amazing place not far from where we live and put in an offer that was accepted. Yesterday, I finally developed the nerve to tell my older sister (I was afraid if I told her earlier she would tell her partner, which I really didn't want) about the money and that we're buying a house and she can sell off this house now if she wants. She went apoplectic. I have never seen her so angry in my whole life. I genuinely thought she would be happy that we're finally stable but she kept screaming at me about why I left it so long to tell her about the money. She eventually stormed out and has been sending me texts about how disappointed she is in me and why I would tell my little sister over her.   


I love my sister but our relationship can be strained. Sometimes it would feel like we should be more grateful to her since she owns our home and we pay very little in rent and she has said to my face that she does so much for our family and we should show a little gratitude. She also does not get along with my little sister which further complicates things. I would have been happy to pay off the mortgage for the house we currently live in and she could always use it as an investment, if she wanted. Now I just feel really bad about everything
model_response:
In this situation, it seems like you are facing a complex emotional landscape with your family dynamics. Here are some points to consider:

1. **Your Decision to Remain Anonymous**: You chose to keep your lottery winnings private, which is your right. Many people prefer to keep such information to themselves to avoid potential complications or expectations from others.

2. **Telling Your Little Sister**: You shared the news with your little sister, which indicates a level of trust and closeness in your relationship with her. It’s understandable that you would want to confide in someone you feel comfortable with.

3. **Your Older Sister's Reaction**: Your older sister's anger seems to stem from feelings of being left out or unappreciated. It’s possible she feels a sense of entitlement or responsibility regarding the family dynamics, especially since she owns the house you all live in. Her reaction may also reflect her own insecurities or fears about the changes your winnings could bring.

4. **Your Intentions**: You had good intentions in wanting to provide a stable home for your family. It sounds like you were trying to make a positive change for everyone involved, including your mother.

5. **Family Dynamics**: The strained relationship between your older sister and your little sister adds another layer of complexity. It’s important to navigate these relationships carefully, as they can influence how everyone reacts to the news.

6. **Feeling Bad**: It’s natural to feel guilty when family members are upset, especially when you care about them. However, it’s also important to remember that you are not responsible for their feelings or reactions. You made a decision that you believed was best for your family.

In conclusion, while your older sister's feelings are valid, your decision to keep your winnings private and to share the news with your little sister first is not inherently wrong. It may be helpful to have an open conversation with your older sister to address her feelings and clarify your intentions. Communication can often help to mend misunderstandings and strengthen relationships.

test_sample.input:
AITA for not telling my sister about my winnings? | To preface; I won just under £3 million on the lottery over two months ago. The NL have been extremely helpful and supportive and gave me lots of financial advice and I've taken it all on board. While I chose to remain anonymous, I did tell my little sister about the winnings, pretty much the second the money hit my account. I still haven't told my mum, I know for sure she would tell everyone she has ever met that I won the lottery and that is absolutely not what I want.  


Me, my sister and mum all live in a small house owned by my older sister, we all used to live here together for many years until my sister bought a house with her partner. We pay her rent, a very small amount and we pay our own utilities. My sister has always hoped she can eventually sell this house to us but neither me nor my little sister have ever had the money. My little sister has a secure job but not very high paying and I am a casual worker so getting a mortgage would be hard for me. After winning, I decided to look for houses that we could move into, ideally one with a large kitchen and garden for my mum and finally found an amazing place not far from where we live and put in an offer that was accepted. Yesterday, I finally developed the nerve to tell my older sister (I was afraid if I told her earlier she would tell her partner, which I really didn't want) about the money and that we're buying a house and she can sell off this house now if she wants. She went apoplectic. I have never seen her so angry in my whole life. I genuinely thought she would be happy that we're finally stable but she kept screaming at me about why I left it so long to tell her about the money. She eventually stormed out and has been sending me texts about how disappointed she is in me and why I would tell my little sister over her.   


I love my sister but our relationship can be strained. Sometimes it would feel like we should be more grateful to her since she owns our home and we pay very little in rent and she has said to my face that she does so much for our family and we should show a little gratitude. She also does not get along with my little sister which further complicates things. I would have been happy to pay off the mortgage for the house we currently live in and she could always use it as an investment, if she wanted. Now I just feel really bad about everything

AITA for missing my brother’s wedding due to a fear of flying? | My older brother is getting married in the spring on the West Coast, where he and his fiancee live, and I live on the East Coast. I’ve been very upfront from the beginning that I won’t be able to make it to his wedding because I have a huge fear of flying/heights, but he won’t listen. He keeps offering to pay for my flights, but the issue isn’t that I don’t have the money for plane tickets, it’s that being that high off the ground terrifies me. I have explained this many, many times. I haven’t set foot on a plane since I was a child, and I’m not sure why he thinks this is magically going to change.  

I did look into alternate transportation options, and it would take me at least five days of traveling to get there and back via bus or train. I just started a new job a few weeks ago and it would look bad if I took that much time off just a few months after starting, so that’s a no go. 

I found out that my brother has been complaining to everyone in our family that I’m not making an effort. First of all, it’s a phobia, meaning it’s not just something I can just get over, and secondly, he and I aren’t even that close, so I don’t know why he’s so insistent on me being there. I’m not even in the wedding party, for God’s sake. AITA?
model_response:
Based on the information you've provided, it seems that you are not the one at fault in this situation. You have communicated your fear of flying clearly and have made an effort to explore alternative transportation options, which unfortunately are not feasible given your new job. It's understandable that your brother may feel disappointed, but it's important for him to recognize that your fear is a legitimate concern and not something you can simply overcome for the occasion.

Your brother's insistence on your attendance, despite your clear explanations, suggests a lack of understanding on his part regarding your phobia. Additionally, since you mentioned that you are not particularly close and are not part of the wedding party, it seems reasonable for you to prioritize your mental well-being and job stability over attending the wedding.

In summary, you are not the asshole (NTA) for missing your brother's wedding due to your fear of flying. It's important for both you and your brother to communicate openly about your feelings and expectations, but ultimately, your mental health should come first.

AITA for defending my choice of gifts? | WeI'm using a throwaway because this sounds bad even to my ears somewhat. The short story of it is, I have a ton of relatives but no actual family. My actual mother died when I was young. My adoptive parents and (some) biological relatives have admitted in therapy that they don't love me and only care for me and give me things out of guilt and obligation. I have higher care expectations placed on me as an "oldest child" that the actually loved family members don't have. All the obligation, no affection.

I'm not angry and I don't cry over it anymore, it's just a little sad to see that all of these people are capable of warm love, just not towards me. I don't do well in relationships and I wouldn't be shocked to die alone. I make terrible choices and I am overly kind and let people walk over me.

I'm not an addict or anything. I'm a standard mid-20s office worker living in the city. I graduated college. I've never been arrested. Never caused issues in school or at home. I'm just deeply unwanted, but I get that health insurance and phone bill covered (not for too long on both) as well as Christmas and birthday gifts.

Naturally, I want higher quality things. The gift train HAS a clear end, and I don't want junk. I need stuff that lasts. So I ask for things like real pearl earrings, good quality beauty products, down comforters, gift cards, and leather shoes (not all in one year obviously). I need good quality stuff, and quite frankly I deserve it as it's not like I get any other benefits of a family. I also don't have qualms about using my status to guilt people into giving me nicer hand me downs. I once made 5 people cry to win myself a solid gold intricate necklace. It's gorgeous.

I've gotten some flak over my asks and the fact that I not only don't avoid animal products but will ask for them. I don't think I should have to care. These things are higher quality. My relatives who are complaining will be getting care for life. I'll only get gifts for a few more years at most.

Edit: I also always give them and their children gifts, although standard ones. I'm not a monster.
model_response:
Your situation sounds incredibly complex and emotionally charged. It’s understandable that you want to make the most of the gifts you receive, especially given the context of your relationships with your relatives. Here are a few points to consider regarding your choices and the reactions you’ve received:

1. **Desire for Quality**: It’s completely valid to want gifts that are meaningful and of good quality, especially if you feel that your relationships with your relatives are transactional. You deserve to receive items that you value and that will last.

2. **Guilt and Obligation**: It seems like there’s a lot of guilt involved in your family dynamics. While it’s understandable to want to leverage your situation to get what you want, it’s also important to consider how this might affect your relationships in the long run. If your relatives feel manipulated or pressured, it could lead to resentment.

3. **Ethical Considerations**: Your choice to ask for items that involve animal products has drawn criticism. While you are entitled to your preferences, being mindful of others’ values can help maintain harmony in your relationships. It might be worth considering how to balance your desires with the feelings of those around you.

4. **Reciprocity**: You mentioned that you give gifts to your relatives and their children. This is a positive aspect of your relationships and shows that you care, even if the gifts are standard. It might help to communicate that you appreciate their gifts and want to reciprocate in a way that feels genuine to you.

5. **Self-Reflection**: It might be helpful to reflect on what you truly want from these relationships beyond material gifts. Building emotional connections, even if they are challenging, could lead to a more fulfilling experience in the long run.

Ultimately, it’s about finding a balance between your needs and the dynamics of your relationships. Open communication with your relatives about your feelings and desires might help clarify expectations and reduce any tension.
